conclusion: Block b is released from a height h = 1.25 m and undergoes an elastic head-on collision with block a.
Using conservation of energy, the velocity of block b at the lowest point of its swing can be calculated as v_1 = sqrt(2gh).
Since the collision is elastic, both momentum and kinetic energy are conserved.
Using conservation of momentum, v_1 = v_a + v_b.
Using conservation of kinetic energy, v_1^2 = v_a^2 + v_b^2.
Substituting v_1 = 5 m/s into the equations: 5 = v_a + v_b and 25 = v_a^2 + v_b^2.
Solving the equations simultaneously gives v_a = 0 or v_a = 5 m/s.
Since v_a = 0 would imply v_b = 5 m/s, which is not possible in an elastic collision where both blocks move, we have v_a = 0 and v_b = 5 m/s.
The velocity of block a just after the collision is v_a = 0 m/s.
Block a starts from rest and moves on the conveyor belt with a velocity v = 2 m/s.
The frictional force acting on block a is F_f = mu mg = 10m N.
The acceleration due to friction is a = F_f/m = 10 m/s^2.
The time taken for block a to come to rest on the conveyor belt is t = v/a = 0.2 s.
The distance traveled in this time is d = 0.2 m.
Since the length of the conveyor belt is l = 1 m, block a will have traveled 0.2 m and will then fall off the conveyor belt.
The velocity of block a just before it leaves the conveyor belt is v = 2 m/s.
Block a then moves on the pipe DE and finally falls off at F.
Using conservation of mechanical energy from the top of the pipe to the bottom, v_{DE} = 4 m/s.
The velocity of block a at the bottom of the pipe is 4 m/s.
The height difference from the bottom of the pipe to the ground is H = 0.2 m.
